Antioch, IL 60002

citations.narrative:
One chinchilla had a chewed up plastic flooring shelf in its enclosure. Two other chinchillas had rust on their grated
flooring. Four ferrets had a rusted feeder. An enclosure containing the pigs had an enclosure/storage shed area that had
been damaged by a fallen tree. A perforated aluminum sheet was sticking out with potentially sharp edges. In addition, at
least two screws were observed to be sticking out on this enclosure/storage shed. The white nose coati had a small
plastic children's play set for it to climb onto. The plastic flooring for this was cracked.
Chewed up or cracked flooring and sharp edges or screws sticking out can cause injury to the animals within that
enclosure. Rusted surfaces or feeders don't allow for those surfaces to be properly sanitized.
All surfaces in these enclosures must be fixed or replaced so their are no sharp edges or points sticking out. Rusted
surfaces should be replaced so those surfaces can be adequately sanitized.

Two goats were housed in an enclosure that did not provide adequate shelter. The shelter they were given had a roof, but
there were no sides. The past few days have been windy and rainy. Not having a shelter with adequate protection from
the wind and rain doesn't afford the goats protection from the elements of the weather. The licensee must provide the
goats a shelter that adequately protects them from the elements of the weather.

Clutter was observed in the enclosure containing the pigs. I observed cans laying around, carriers were stored in the
enclosure, various wooden structures and wood boards were laying around throughout the enclosure. Clutter can
potentially cause injury to the animals within the enclosure. All clutter should be removed from the enclosure.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by December 31st, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License
Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
End of report.
n

narrative:
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
One chinchilla had a chewed up plastic flooring shelf in its enclosure. Two other chinchillas had rust on their grated 
flooring. Four ferrets had a rusted feeder. An enclosure containing the pigs had an enclosure/storage shed area that had 
been damaged by a fallen tree. A perforated aluminum sheet was sticking out with potentially sharp edges. In addition, at 
least two screws were observed to be sticking out on this enclosure/storage shed. The white nose coati had a small 
plastic children's play set for it to climb onto. The plastic flooring for this was cracked. 
 
Chewed up or cracked flooring and sharp edges or screws sticking out can cause injury to the animals within that 
enclosure. Rusted surfaces or feeders don't allow for those surfaces to be properly sanitized. 
 
All surfaces in these enclosures must be fixed or replaced so their are no sharp edges or points sticking out. Rusted 
surfaces should be replaced so those surfaces can be adequately sanitized. 
3.127(b) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
Two goats were housed in an enclosure that did not provide adequate shelter. The shelter they were given had a roof, but 
there were no sides. The past few days have been windy and rainy. Not having a shelter with adequate protection from 
the wind and rain doesn't afford the goats protection from the elements of the weather. The licensee must provide the 
goats a shelter that adequately protects them from the elements of the weather. 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
Clutter was observed in the enclosure containing the pigs. I observed cans laying around, carriers were stored in the 
enclosure, various wooden structures and wood boards were laying around throughout the enclosure. Clutter can 
potentially cause injury to the animals within the enclosure. All clutter should be removed from the enclosure. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant.

All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by December 31st, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the 
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License 
Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
End of report. 
 
 n
